I studied low-resolution, multi-epoch, ultraviolet spectra from 8 type Ia supernovae observed with the Hubble Space Telescope. I looked for variability in the narrow absorption lines that come from ionizing circumstellar material surrounding their progenitor systems after the explosion, specifically analyzing iron and magnesium absorption features. To do this, I wrote a Python script that measured the equivalent widths of these absorption features by integrating over a Gaussian function fit to the lines in a normalized spectrum. These lines have never been studied before, and this project hopes to reveal new information about the circumstellar material surrounding Type Ia supernovae. However, in our best examples, we haven’t detected any significant variable features, indicating that these features didn’t arise from the gas near the explosion.
